title: UniMTS-Inspired Orientation Invariance Experiments
summary: SO(3) rotation augmentation hurts magnetometer-based finger classification because absolute magnetic field direction is discriminative

so3_rotation.reason: Destroys absolute magnetic field direction which is discriminative

physics_augmentation.reason: Bias and rotation perturbations shift the signal too much

oit_features.reason: 9-element heuristic features lose too much information

contrastive_pretrain.reason: Best augmentation method but still worse than baseline

small_angle_rotation.finding: 5° rotation slightly improves over baseline (96.6% vs 93.5%)

key_insights: Magnetometer readings shift 348-2155% of std between orientations
SO(3) rotation randomizes absolute position, destroying signal
Small-angle rotation (5°) may slightly help without destroying signal
3D vector representation outperforms magnitude-only or spherical
Orientation-invariance is the WRONG goal for this task
V3 baseline achieves 96.4% without any rotation augmentation

fundamental_difference.gesture_recognition: Same gesture at different orientations should match -> want invariance
fundamental_difference.finger_classification: Same finger state produces different mag values at different orientations -> want sensitivity

recommendation: Keep V3 baseline. Optionally add 5° small-angle rotation for slight improvement. Do not use full SO(3) rotation or orientation-invariant transforms.
